hints.content:
Every coin has a different value.

Coin name | Picture | Value
- | - | -
Penny | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/d0799f515398b1f48cb0baa7bdc8d0c12e26c70c.png) | $1¢$
Nickel | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/f6c7ae82228012be92b624995809aeabc8e95370.png) | $5¢$
Dime | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/2017369b968caa0c88d046bddf2406665c8cd34d.png) | $10¢$
Quarter | ![](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/1cc5cb6f4c779c49984f5a63a58443ce0ca96ff9.png) | $25¢$

Let's label the value of each set of coins and find the total.

###$1$ quarter, $1$ dime, $2$ nickels, and $2$ pennies

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{1}{\text{ quarter}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{1}{\text{ dime}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}}_{\maroonD{2}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{1}{\text{ quarter}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{1}{\text{ dime}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{10¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{2¢}}_{\maroonD{2}{\text{ pennies}}}=47¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $47¢$, so it is **not** equal to $79¢$.

###$1$ quarter, $2$ dimes, $2$ nickels, and $4$ pennies

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{1}{\text{ quarter}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{2}{\text{ dimes}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}+\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{1}{\text{ quarter}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{20¢}}_{\purpleD{2}{\text{ dimes}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{10¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=59¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $59¢$, so it is **not** equal to $79¢$.

###$1$ quarter, $4$ dimes, $2$ nickels, and $4$ pennies

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{1}{\text{ quarter}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{4}{\text{ dimes}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}+\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{1}{\text{ quarter}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{40¢}}_{\purpleD{4}{\text{ dimes}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{10¢}}_{\goldE{2}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=79¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $79¢$, so it **is** equal to Raj's amount of money.

Raj could have this set of coins:

$1$ quarter, $4$ dimes, $2$ nickels, and $4$ pennies

question.content:
Raj has $79¢$.

**Which set of coins could Raj have?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
